ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Live virtual discussions.

This year, Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays were in the format I indicated in part a. Tuesdays and Thursdays were mostly asynchronous. On those days, sometimes we had a recorded class / lecture or sometimes a different type of asynchronous activity.
We met 3 or 4 times a week in a virtual small class/seminar format. The other 2 times a week we watched recorded learning videos.
There were also prerecorded lectures for asynchronous days and a lot of practice available on the Canvas site.
Half synchronous zoom meetings and half asynchronous activities.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better understanding of the language

I feel that I dramatically improved my Spanish speaking ability over the past three months to a level that it has never been to before. I have improved my reading comprehension, speaking, as well as my spoken fluidity
I learned how to read, write, and speak Spanish at an intermediate level. There was a main stress on writing, but I did need ample practice in this subject anyway!

I was skeptical about how much my Spanish could actually improve in a class conducted on Zoom, but by the end of the semester I felt that my Spanish, particularly my reading and writing, had improved fairly substantially. My speaking and listening improved as well, but not as much, which makes sense because we unfortunately didn't get to speak and listen to each other in person.
I got better at speaking Spanish in this course

This course really helps you improve upon your reading, listening, speaking, and writing. There is a focus on grammar, and this information applies to every form of communication in Spanish. I also felt like I learned how to think in Spanish.
I really improved my speaking as we used the breakout rooms a lot. I think I learnt more grammatically and I think L3 explains the concepts well. Also, there was a lot to learn about Spanish culture.

I developed a better mastery of Spanish speaking, reading, and writing with particular focus on the two past tenses (preterite and imperfect).  I also learned valuable sentence structures, connecting clauses, and conjugations in the future and subjunctive tenses.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Diaz really cares about educating his students on the intricacies of the spanish language.

Weaknesses: This class is a lot of work. There is little helpful feedback given Professor Diaz can be sexist at times, and will whistle or click at female students.
The course was very fast paced.
I think that the course was well made for the circumstances and I don't have many things to complain about.

The cyclic nature of the course made it easy to schedule around. I loved the organization and thoughtfulness of the professor. I truly enjoyed the cultural assignments that involved reading or watching stories from other countries.

I thought the readings, short films, the novel, and the movie at the end of the semester were all strengths of the course. The activities that simply involved talking between two students were also very helpful. Probably the least helpful parts of the course were when the entire class was together, learning from a slideshow presentation, because it was easier to become disengaged in that setting. I would push for more activities involving talking between two or three students, and less lecture-style presentations, although I understand that sometimes those presentations are necessary and useful.

I think that a weakness of this course was the poor scheduling of the assessments. Some weeks we had multiple assessments and other weeks we had no assessments. Another weakness of this class was that sometimes instructions for assignments were unclear, and towards the end of the semester we were assigned excessive amounts of readings for our book: relato de naufraugo. One strength of this class was that because we only met usually 3x a week, we were able to take our time and review on our own on the other two days. Another strength, was that the professor provided extra modules for us to watch and it definitely helped me understand the material better.
The strengths are the in class presentations to learn maters and the weaknesses are the in book learning opportunities.

The course is designed really well. There was an abundance of work that helped me improve upon the areas I was weak in and truly become a better speaker and writer of Spanish. I did not think there were too many weaknesses to the course. If you put effort into this class, it pays off greatly.

I think this course immerses you into Spanish culture and watching/reading Spanish media made the course really engaging. Sometimes the textbook work was not always useful though. But supersite was very good.

I thought the course was extremely immersive and one of the harder classes I've ever taken.  I found the recorded explanations of grammar lessons (on Loom) to be extremely helpful, but the amount of extra worksheets and exercises seemed too extensive at points.  It also made it hard to narrow down what to specifically study for the exams; however, communication between the teaching team, professor, and students was excellent and the rubric for every assignment was very transparent and understandable.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think decreasing the number of days the course meets was effective, but perhaps more learning should have been done during live class with practice to be done on asynchronous days.
I think that the breakout rooms were a great inclusion and I really enjoyed the one-on-one discussions that I had with other students in my class.

There is a lot more that the Spanish department can do to make this course more manageable and flexible for people-- the workload is frankly not realistic but I appreciated the professor's kindness and genuine interest in seeing us improve and learn.
There were times when the breakout rooms were less productive than planned. I think group activities always keep students engaged otherwise.
I think that the virtual supersite tarea was helpful sometimes, but assigning it everyday for homework made it turn into busywork and not necessarily productive work.
The use of breakout rooms to discuss different topics with classmates was very useful.

I think the Zooms had a great mix of lecture and speaking with other students in breakout rooms. The availability of online resources was probably my favorite part of the entire course. The Canvas site had so much to offer, and the professor was always willing to help. I think the tests maintained a great format in spite of coronavirus as well.

I think the synchronous classes worked extremely well.  Asynchronous content was helpful, but there tended to be a lot of worksheets and handouts, some of which were required and others which were supplemental.  Some delineation might be helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it was a good way to enhance my understanding of the language.

I definitely would. The workload was a little high but it was by no means unjustified. All the content, in my opinion, very strongly affected my comprehension of the language and improved my overall proficiency.
I think this class does an excellent job in teaching spanish. I would recommend to anyone wanting to seriously learn. Beware, it is a lot of work! But that's necessary to learning any language well.

I would recommend this course to a student looking to actually improve his or her Spanish. The class isn't necessarily as challenging as other courses, but work is required in order to get the benefits of the class. The work is not very difficult, but daily practice is important to make sure your Spanish improves. Although it may not be as exciting as some other courses, it is still fun, enjoyable, and helps you learn Spanish.
I would recommend this course to another student, but probably not during COVID times. I think that it is hard to maintain engagement in this course in the virtual format.
Yes. I feel like Spanish is a good language to learn and they do a good job making you able to write and speak it

I would definitely recommend this course. You can learn so much in just so much semester. By the end of the class, you will have a much greater understanding of both Spanish language and culture. You must be prepared to do a fair amount of work, but it never feels too burdensome. It was also a fun class experience because it allowed a lot of interaction with other students though breakout rooms in Zoom.
Yes, with the warning that it is much more intensive than Spanish L1 or L2.
